facts: The first widely known home video game console, the Magnavox Odyssey, was released in 1972 and used simple screen overlays instead of detailed graphics.
A game controller’s directional pad (D-pad) became popular after Nintendo used it on the Game & Watch handhelds and later on the NES controller.
Many modern video games use a “game engine,” which is software that handles graphics, physics, sound, and other tools so developers can build games faster.
Video games often use “frame rate” to measure smoothness, and higher frame rates can make motion look more fluid during fast action.
Online multiplayer games rely on computer servers to connect players, and the time it takes data to travel is called “latency” or “ping.”
The ESRB rating system in the United States helps families choose games by labeling age recommendations and content like violence or language.
Speedrunning is a hobby where players try to finish games as fast as possible, sometimes using clever strategies and glitches to save time.
